title: Financial Statement Analysis – Ultra Detailed Revision Edition
overview: Financial Statement Analysis (20% of Part 2) is about reading between the numbers. It requires mastery of comparative analysis techniques (horizontal, vertical, common-size), all five ratio categories (Liquidity, Leverage, Activity, Profitability, Market), the DuPont framework, profitability decomposition, and special issues including foreign currency translation, inflation effects, and earnings quality. The CMA exam tests interpretation and judgment — not just formula recall. You must be able to analyze trends, identify red flags, evaluate performance against benchmarks, and understand how accounting choices affect ratios. This section bridges raw financial data with strategic business decisions.
bulletNotes: **Horizontal Analysis (Trend)**: (Current Year – Base Year) / Base Year × 100%. Base year is denominator. Identifies growth patterns and turning points.
**Vertical Analysis (Common-Size)**: Each line as % of base (IS: Net Sales; BS: Total Assets). Enables size-independent comparisons across companies and periods.

**Liquidity Ratios – Ability to Pay Short-Term Debt**: Current Ratio (CA/CL) ≥2; Quick Ratio (excludes inventory) ≥1; Cash Ratio (most conservative). Watch for excess inventory inflating Current Ratio.

**Leverage Ratios – Long-Term Solvency Risk**: Debt-to-Equity (TD/TE) – higher = more risk; Times Interest Earned (EBIT/Interest) – <1 means can't cover interest; Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity) – DuPont component.
**Activity Ratios – Efficiency**: Inventory Turnover (COGS/Avg Inv); AR Turnover (Credit Sales/Avg AR); AP Turnover (COGS/Avg AP); Asset Turnover (Sales/Avg Assets). Always use AVERAGE balances.
**Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC)**: Days Inventory + DSO – DPO. Lower is better. Negative CCC = suppliers finance operations (retailers).
**Profitability Ratios**: Gross Margin (GP/Sales); Operating Margin (EBIT/Sales); Net Margin (NI/Sales); ROA (NI/Avg Assets); ROE (NI/Avg Equity). Compare to industry benchmarks.
**DuPont (3-factor)**: ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier. Decomposes ROE into profitability, efficiency, and leverage. #1 tested framework.
**Market Ratios**: P/E (Price/EPS) – growth expectations; Dividend Yield (DPS/Price) – income return; Dividend Payout (DPS/EPS) – % of earnings paid out.
**Basic vs Diluted EPS**: Diluted ≤ Basic. Diluted includes options, convertibles, contingently issuable shares.

**FX Translation – Critical Difference**: Current Rate Method (independent sub, functional currency = local) → Translation adjustment to OCI. Temporal Method (integrated sub, functional currency = parent) → Remeasurement gain/loss to Net Income. Memory: Current = Cushioned (OCI), Temporal = Tough (hits Income).

**Monetary vs Non-Monetary**: Monetary = fixed dollar amount (Cash, AR, AP, Debt) – translated at current rate under Temporal. Non-monetary = Inventory, PPE, Prepaids – translated at historical rate under Temporal.
**Earnings Quality Indicators – High Quality**: Recurring (core operations), Cash-backed (CFO ≈ NI), Conservative accounting, Consistent policies.
**Earnings Quality Red Flags**: NI >> CFO (accruals not converting); Frequent accounting changes; Large one-time gains; Channel stuffing; Capitalizing expenses; Aggressive revenue recognition.
**Inflation Effects**: Distorts historical cost – FIFO overstates real profit; Depreciation understated; Real profitability lower than reported.
**No.1 Exam Trap**: Using year-end balances instead of AVERAGES for ratios mixing IS (flow) and BS (point) data (ROA, Turnover ratios).
**DuPont Insight**: ROE can increase due to higher leverage even when business is deteriorating – always analyze components.
**DSO Interpretation**: Lower DSO = faster collection = better. Higher DSO may indicate collection problems or liberal credit terms.
shortNotes: Always use AVERAGE balance sheet figures when mixing with income statement data (ROA, Turnover ratios). DuPont is the #1 tested framework — know all three components and what drives each. For FX: Current Rate = OCI; Temporal = Net Income. Earnings quality questions require judgment about sustainability of reported earnings. Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC) measures operating efficiency – lower is better. Remember that ROE can be inflated by leverage – always check DuPont components. Watch for red flags: NI > CFO, inventory growing faster than sales, DSO increasing.

concepts.title: 1. Comparative Financial Statement Analysis
concepts.content:
Horizontal Analysis (Trend Analysis)

Compares financial data across multiple periods to identify trends, growth rates, and patterns. Essential for spotting turning points (acceleration/deceleration).

  • Formula: (Current Year Amount – Base Year Amount) / Base Year Amount × 100%
  • Base year is always the denominator – choose a representative year (not an outlier).
  • Can be applied to any line item: Revenue, COGS, Net Income, Assets, Liabilities.
  • Example: Revenue grew from $500K (Year 1) to $600K (Year 2) → Change = $100K / $500K = 20% increase.
  • Analytical Insight: Compare growth rates of related items. If Revenue grows 10% but AR grows 25% → collection problems. If Inventory grows 15% but COGS grows 5% → potential overstocking.

Vertical Analysis (Common-Size Statements)

Expresses each line item as a percentage of a base figure within the same period. Eliminates size differences, enabling comparison across companies and time.

  • Income Statement: Each item as % of Net Sales/Revenue. Example: COGS = $300K, Sales = $500K → COGS % = 60%.
  • Balance Sheet: Each item as % of Total Assets. Example: Inventory = $100K, Total Assets = $1M → Inventory % = 10%.
  • Purpose:
    • Compare company to competitors (regardless of size).
    • Identify structural changes over time (e.g., Gross Margin % declining may indicate pricing pressure).
    • Assess asset composition (e.g., increasing % of AR may indicate credit sales growth).

Trend Analysis with Index Numbers

Uses an index to compare multiple years to a single base year (base year = 100).

  • If Year 1 (base) = 100, Year 2 = 110, Year 3 = 125 → revenue grew 25% from base year.
  • Useful for visualizing growth trajectories and identifying when growth is slowing (Year 2: +10%, Year 3: +13.6% from Year 2? Actually 125/110 = 13.6% growth rate from Year 2 to Year 3).

concepts.title: 2. Liquidity Ratios – Short-Term Solvency
concepts.content:
Measure the company's ability to meet short-term obligations (due within one year) as they come due. Critical for assessing bankruptcy risk.

RatioFormulaInterpretationExam Tips
Current RatioCurrent Assets / Current Liabilities>2 = strong; <1 = potential liquidity crisis. Includes inventory and prepaids.High ratio may indicate excess inventory or uncollected receivables – not always good.
Quick Ratio (Acid-Test)(Cash + Marketable Securities + Net AR) / Current Liabilities>1 = good; excludes inventory and prepaids. More conservative than Current Ratio.Best measure of true short-term liquidity. If <1, company relies on inventory sales to pay bills.
Cash Ratio(Cash + Marketable Securities) / Current LiabilitiesMost conservative measure. Immediate payment ability without selling inventory or collecting AR.Very low in most companies; used by creditors in extreme cases.
Net Working CapitalCurrent Assets – Current LiabilitiesAbsolute dollar measure of liquidity buffer. Positive = current assets exceed current liabilities.Useful for size comparison but not for cross-company analysis.
Cash Flow RatioCash Flow from Operations (CFO) / Current LiabilitiesUses actual cash generated, not accrual-based assets. Better indicator of sustainable liquidity.If CFO consistently negative, liquidity problems likely despite high Current Ratio.

Key Insight – The 'Liquidity Trap': A high current ratio is not always good. It may indicate:

  • Excess slow-moving inventory (obsolescence risk).
  • Uncollected receivables (collection problems).
  • Cash not being invested productively.

Always compare the Quick Ratio to assess true liquidity. If Current Ratio > 2 but Quick Ratio < 1, the company is heavily dependent on inventory to meet obligations – risky if inventory is hard to sell quickly.

concepts.title: 3. Leverage (Solvency) Ratios – Long-Term Risk
concepts.content:
Measure the extent to which a company uses debt financing and its ability to service that debt over the long term. Higher leverage amplifies returns but also increases risk of bankruptcy.

RatioFormulaInterpretationExam Tips
Debt-to-Equity (D/E)Total Liabilities / Total Shareholders' EquityHigher = more leverage = more risk. >1 means more debt than equity.Compare to industry norms – capital-intensive industries have higher D/E.
Debt-to-AssetsTotal Debt / Total AssetsPercentage of assets financed by creditors. >50% means more debt than equity financing.Complement to D/E. (D/A = D/E / (1 + D/E)).
Equity MultiplierTotal Assets / Total EquityDuPont component. Higher = more leverage. EM = 1 / (1 – D/A).If EM = 2, assets are twice equity → 50% debt financing.
Times Interest Earned (TIE) / Interest CoverageEBIT / Interest ExpenseHow many times EBIT covers interest payments. <1.5 = danger zone; <1 = cannot cover interest from operations.Use EBIT (not EBITDA) for conservative measure. Some analysts use EBITDA for higher coverage.
Debt Service Coverage (DSC)EBIT / (Interest + Principal Repayment / (1 – Tax Rate))Covers both interest AND principal payments (principal must be paid with after-tax cash).More comprehensive than TIE. Principal repayment is not tax-deductible.
Fixed Charge Coverage(EBIT + Lease Payments) / (Interest + Lease Payments)Includes operating lease payments as fixed charges (important under ASC 842).Broader measure of fixed obligations.

Financial Leverage – Double-Edged Sword:

  • When ROA > Cost of Debt: Leverage amplifies ROE (positive).
  • When ROA < Cost of Debt: Leverage destroys ROE (negative).
  • Leverage increases financial risk – earnings become more volatile, and bankruptcy risk rises.

concepts.title: 4. Activity (Efficiency) Ratios
concepts.content:
Measure how efficiently a company manages its assets to generate revenue. These ratios indicate operational effectiveness and working capital management.

RatioFormulaDays EquivalentInterpretation
Inventory TurnoverCOGS / Average InventoryDays Inventory = 365 / Inv TurnoverHigher = faster inventory movement. Low may indicate obsolescence or overstocking.
Accounts Receivable TurnoverNet Credit Sales / Average ARDays Sales Outstanding (DSO) = 365 / AR TurnoverHigher = faster collection. DSO increasing may indicate collection problems.
Accounts Payable TurnoverCOGS / Average APDays Payables Outstanding (DPO) = 365 / AP TurnoverLower = slower payment (conserves cash). But too low may strain supplier relationships.
Asset TurnoverNet Sales / Average Total AssetsN/ARevenue generated per $ of assets. Higher = more efficient asset use.
Fixed Asset TurnoverNet Sales / Average Net Fixed AssetsN/AEfficiency of long-term assets (PP&E). Low may indicate excess capacity.

Critical Rule – Use AVERAGES: For all turnover ratios, use average balance sheet figures (beginning + ending) / 2. Because income statement covers a period, balance sheet is a point in time. This is the #1 most common exam mistake.

Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC) – The Ultimate Efficiency Metric

CCC = Days Inventory Outstanding (DIO) + Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) – Days Payables Outstanding (DPO)

  • Measures how long cash is tied up in operations – from paying for inventory to collecting cash from customers.
  • Lower CCC = Better – cash is recycled faster, reducing financing needs.
  • Negative CCC (e.g., Amazon, Walmart, Dell) means suppliers finance operations: company collects cash from customers BEFORE paying suppliers.
  • Operating Cycle: DIO + DSO (excludes payables). Measures time from inventory purchase to cash collection.

Example: DIO = 40 days, DSO = 30 days, DPO = 35 days → CCC = 40 + 30 – 35 = 35 days. Cash tied up for 35 days.

concepts.title: 5. Profitability Ratios
concepts.content:
Measure the company's ability to generate profit relative to sales, assets, and equity. These are the most closely watched ratios by investors.

RatioFormulaWhat It MeasuresExam Tips
Gross Profit MarginGross Profit / Net SalesPricing power, production efficiency, cost of goods sold management.Compare to industry. Declining margin may indicate competition or rising input costs.
Operating Profit MarginEBIT / Net SalesCore operating profitability before financing and taxes.Excludes non-operating items. Best measure of operational efficiency.
Net Profit MarginNet Income / Net SalesBottom-line profitability after all costs, interest, and taxes.Can be distorted by one-time items, tax effects, and financing structure.
EBITDA MarginEBITDA / Net SalesCash-generating ability before financing, taxes, depreciation, and amortization.Used in valuation; approximates operating cash flow potential.
Return on Assets (ROA)Net Income / Average Total AssetsReturn generated on all assets employed. Measures overall profitability relative to asset base.Use average assets. Low ROA may indicate poor asset utilization or low margins.
Return on Equity (ROE)Net Income / Average Shareholders' EquityReturn to common shareholders. Most important to investors.Can be decomposed via DuPont. Compare to cost of equity.
Return on Capital Employed (ROCE)EBIT / (Total Assets – Current Liabilities)Return on long-term capital (debt + equity). Useful for capital-intensive industries.Measures profitability of capital employed.

Earnings Per Share (EPS)

Basic EPS: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares Outstanding

  • Preferred dividends are subtracted because they are not available to common shareholders.
  • Weighted average shares account for stock issuances, repurchases, and stock dividends during the year.

Diluted EPS: Includes the effect of all potential dilutive securities (stock options, convertible bonds, convertible preferred stock, warrants).

  • Always ≤ Basic EPS. Dilution reduces EPS.
  • If a security is anti-dilutive (increases EPS), it is EXCLUDED from diluted EPS calculation.
  • Calculated using the treasury stock method for options and the if-converted method for convertibles.

concepts.title: 6. Market (Valuation) Ratios
concepts.content:
Relate market price to financial performance metrics. These ratios reflect investor expectations and market sentiment.

RatioFormulaInterpretationExam Tips
Price/Earnings (P/E)Market Price per Share / EPSHow much investors pay per $1 of earnings. Higher P/E = higher growth expectations.Compare to industry average and historical P/E. Very high P/E may indicate overvaluation.
Earnings YieldEPS / Market Price per ShareInverse of P/E. Return on market price. Useful for comparing to bond yields.If earnings yield < risk-free rate, stock may be overvalued.
Dividend YieldDividends per Share / Market Price per ShareIncome return on investment. Important for income-oriented investors.High yield may indicate stock price decline (yield increases as price falls).
Dividend Payout RatioDividends per Share / EPSPercentage of earnings paid out as dividends. <1 means retained earnings.High payout may indicate limited growth opportunities; low payout may indicate reinvestment.
Market-to-Book RatioMarket Price per Share / Book Value per Share>1 = market values firm above accounting value (goodwill, intangibles, growth expectations).<1 may indicate undervaluation or asset impairment issues.
Book Value per Share(Total Equity – Preferred Equity) / Common Shares OutstandingAccounting value per common share. Based on historical cost.May understate economic value for companies with significant intangible assets.

concepts.title: 7. DuPont Analysis – Decomposing ROE (CRITICAL)
concepts.content:
DuPont analysis breaks ROE into components to identify the drivers of return. This is the #1 most tested framework in Financial Statement Analysis.

3-Factor DuPont Model

ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

ROE = (Net Income / Sales) × (Sales / Average Assets) × (Average Assets / Average Equity)

ComponentMeasuresDriven ByFormula
Net Profit MarginProfitability per dollar of salesPricing strategy, cost control, tax management, operating efficiencyNI / Sales
Asset TurnoverEfficiency of asset utilizationRevenue generation from assets, working capital management, capacity utilizationSales / Avg Assets
Equity MultiplierFinancial leverage (risk)Debt vs equity financing mixAvg Assets / Avg Equity

5-Factor DuPont Model (Extended)

ROE = Tax Burden × Interest Burden × EBIT Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

  • Tax Burden: Net Income / Earnings Before Tax (EBT). Measures percentage of pre-tax income kept after taxes. Lower tax rate = higher burden.
  • Interest Burden: EBT / EBIT. Measures impact of interest expense. Lower interest expense = higher burden.
  • EBIT Margin: EBIT / Sales. Operating profitability before interest and taxes.

Analytical Insights from DuPont

  • If ROE increases, ask WHY?
    • Higher Margin → better pricing or cost control (sustainable).
    • Higher Turnover → more efficient asset use (sustainable).
    • Higher Leverage → more debt (increases risk, may not be sustainable).
  • Exam Trap: ROE can increase due to higher leverage even when the business is deteriorating (lower margins, lower turnover). Always analyze components.
  • Compare to competitors: If Company A has higher ROE than Company B, DuPont shows whether it's due to better operations (margin/turnover) or simply more risk (leverage).

Example Analysis:

  • Company X: ROE = 15% (Margin 5%, Turnover 2.0, EM 1.5)
  • Company Y: ROE = 15% (Margin 10%, Turnover 1.0, EM 1.5)
  • Company X generates return through efficiency (turnover), Company Y through high margins. Different business models, both valid.

concepts.title: 8. Profitability Analysis – Revenue, Cost & Variation
concepts.content:
Revenue Analysis

  • Source Analysis: Breakdown by product line, geography, customer segment, distribution channel. Identifies concentration risks (if one customer >10% of revenue).
  • Stability: Recurring revenue (subscriptions, contracts) vs one-time sales. Higher recurring revenue = more predictable earnings.
  • Trend Analysis: Compare revenue growth to industry growth. If company grows faster than industry, gaining market share.
  • Relationship with Receivables: If AR grows faster than revenue → collection problems or looser credit terms. DSO increasing is a red flag.
  • Relationship with Inventory: If inventory grows faster than revenue → potential overstocking, obsolescence, or demand slowdown.

Cost of Sales Analysis

  • Gross Margin Trend: Declining margin may indicate:
    • Rising input costs (not passed to customers).
    • Pricing pressure from competition.
    • Product mix shift toward lower-margin products.
    • Inefficient production.
  • Compare to Industry: If company margin significantly above peers, assess sustainability (patents, brand, efficiency).

Expense Analysis

  • Operating Leverage: High fixed costs (e.g., manufacturing, R&D) → profits more sensitive to revenue changes. Small revenue decline can cause large profit drop.
  • SG&A as % of Sales: Rising % may indicate inefficiency, overhead growth outpacing revenue, or increased marketing spending.
  • R&D as % of Sales: Declining R&D may boost short-term profits but hurt long-term competitiveness.

Variation Analysis

  • Identify unusual fluctuations in line items period-over-period.
  • Investigate items that deviate significantly from trend (e.g., 'Other Income' spike may be one-time asset sale).
  • Look for 'cookie jar' reserves – reducing provisions to boost earnings.

concepts.title: 9. Special Issues – Foreign Currency Translation
concepts.content:
When a parent company consolidates a foreign subsidiary, the subsidiary's financial statements must be translated into the parent's reporting currency. The method depends on the subsidiary's functional currency.

Functional Currency Determination

  • Functional Currency: Primary currency of the economic environment in which the subsidiary operates.
  • Local Currency: Currency of the country where subsidiary is located.
  • Parent's Currency: Reporting currency of the parent.
ScenarioFunctional CurrencyTranslation Method
Subsidiary is relatively independent (operates locally, cash flows in local currency)Local currencyCurrent Rate Method
Subsidiary is integrated with parent (depends on parent for financing, cash flows remitted to parent)Parent's currencyTemporal Method

Current Rate Method (Independent Subsidiary)

  • Assets & Liabilities: Translated at current (spot) rate at balance sheet date.
  • Revenue & Expenses: Translated at average rate for the period (or weighted average).
  • Equity: Translated at historical rate (when issued).
  • Translation Gain/Loss: Reported in Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) – does NOT hit Net Income. Accumulated in a separate equity account (Cumulative Translation Adjustment).
  • Memory Aid: Current Rate = Cushioned (OCI).

Temporal Method (Integrated Subsidiary)

  • Monetary Assets & Liabilities: Cash, AR, AP, Debt → translated at current rate.
  • Non-Monetary Assets & Liabilities: Inventory, PPE, Prepaids, Intangibles → translated at historical rate (rate when acquired).
  • Revenue & Expenses: Most at average rate; COGS and Depreciation at historical rate (matching the related assets).
  • Remeasurement Gain/Loss: Reported in Net Income – directly affects earnings.
  • Memory Aid: Temporal = Tough (hits Income).

Monetary vs Non-Monetary Assets:

  • Monetary: Represent fixed dollar amounts (Cash, AR, AP, Notes Payable, Dividends Payable).
  • Non-Monetary: Do not represent fixed dollar amounts (Inventory, PPE, Prepaid Expenses, Intangibles, Goodwill).

Exam Tip: Questions often describe the subsidiary's operations – if it's a self-contained foreign operation (e.g., French subsidiary selling in euros, paying French taxes, borrowing from French banks), use Current Rate → OCI. If it's an extension of parent (e.g., assembly plant that ships all output to parent), use Temporal → Net Income.

concepts.title: 10. Special Issues – Inflation, Accounting Changes & Earnings Quality
concepts.content:
Effects of Changing Prices / Inflation

  • Historical Cost Distortion: Financial statements under historical cost do not reflect current values during inflation.
  • Inventory Effects: Under FIFO, older (lower) costs matched against current revenues → overstates profit and taxes; inventory valued at older costs understates replacement cost.
  • Depreciation: Depreciation on older assets based on historical cost understates true economic depreciation; net income overstated.
  • Monetary Items: Holding monetary assets (cash, AR) during inflation loses purchasing power; holding monetary liabilities (debt) gains purchasing power (pay back with cheaper currency).
  • Analyst Adjustments: May use constant dollar accounting or current cost accounting to assess real performance.

Impact of Changes in Accounting Treatment

  • Accounting Policy Changes: e.g., switching from LIFO to FIFO, changing depreciation method, revenue recognition changes.
  • Effect on Comparability: Prior periods must be restated to enable apples-to-apples comparison. If not restated, analyst must adjust.
  • Estimate Changes: e.g., useful life of asset, bad debt percentage. These are prospective (affect current and future periods only).
  • Red Flag: Frequent accounting changes may indicate earnings management.

Earnings Quality

High-quality earnings are:

  • Recurring: From core operations, not one-time gains (asset sales, legal settlements, tax credits).
  • Cash-Backed: Supported by operating cash flow. Ratio of CFO to Net Income should be close to 1 over time. If NI consistently > CFO, earnings may be low quality.
  • Conservative: Not inflated by aggressive accounting choices (capitalizing expenses, extending useful lives, low bad debt estimates).
  • Consistent: Same accounting policies applied period to period.
  • Achieved Through Operations: Not from favorable tax rates or accounting changes.

Red Flags for Low Earnings Quality (Exam Checklist):

  • Net Income >> Cash Flow from Operations (accruals not converting to cash).
  • Frequent changes in accounting estimates (useful lives, bad debt %).
  • Large non-recurring gains (selling assets, one-time settlements) boosting income.
  • Channel stuffing (inflating revenue by shipping excess inventory to distributors near period end).
  • Capitalizing expenses that should be expensed (e.g., software development, marketing).
  • Aggressive revenue recognition (recognizing before delivery, before customer acceptance).
  • Related-party transactions with favorable terms.
  • Build-up of inventory relative to sales (may indicate obsolescence or overproduction to absorb fixed overhead).
  • DSO increasing (may indicate looser credit terms to boost sales).

Accounting vs Economic Value

  • Book Value (Accounting): Based on historical cost minus depreciation. May bear little relation to market value.
  • Economic Value: Present value of future cash flows discounted at appropriate cost of capital. Reflects true worth.
  • Market Value: Stock price times shares outstanding. Reflects investor expectations of future economic value.
  • Reasons for Differences: Intangible assets not on balance sheet (brand, talent, customer relationships), inflation, growth opportunities, market sentiment.

formulas.name: Quick Ratio
formulas.formula: (Cash + Marketable Securities + Net Accounts Receivable) / Current Liabilities

formulas.name: Inventory Turnover
formulas.formula: Cost of Goods Sold / Average Inventory

formulas.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
formulas.formula: Net Credit Sales / Average Accounts Receivable

formulas.name: Accounts Payable Turnover
formulas.formula: Cost of Goods Sold / Average Accounts Payable

formulas.name: Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC)
formulas.formula: Days Inventory Outstanding + Days Sales Outstanding – Days Payables Outstanding

formulas.name: Fixed Asset Turnover
formulas.formula: Net Sales / Average Net Fixed Assets

formulas.name: DuPont ROE (3-factor)
formulas.formula: Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

formulas.name: Basic Earnings Per Share (EPS)
formulas.formula: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares Outstanding

formulas.name: Diluted EPS
formulas.formula: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / (Weighted Average Shares + Dilutive Securities)

formulas.name: Price/Earnings (P/E) Ratio
formulas.formula: Market Price per Share / Earnings Per Share

formulas.name: Dividend Yield
formulas.formula: Dividends per Share / Market Price per Share

formulas.name: Dividend Payout Ratio
formulas.formula: Dividends per Share / Earnings Per Share

formulas.name: Book Value per Share
formulas.formula: (Total Equity – Preferred Equity) / Common Shares Outstanding

formulas.name: Market-to-Book Ratio
formulas.formula: Market Price per Share / Book Value per Share

mistakes: Using **end-of-year** balance sheet figures instead of **averages** for ratios that mix income statement (flow) and balance sheet (point) data – ROA, Turnover ratios, ROE.
Forgetting to subtract **Preferred Dividends** from Net Income when calculating Basic EPS or ROE available to common shareholders.
Confusing **Current Rate Method** (translation adjustment to OCI) with **Temporal Method** (remeasurement gain/loss to Net Income). Memory: Current = Cushioned (OCI), Temporal = Tough (Income).
Thinking a **lower DSO** is bad. Lower DSO means faster collection – it is GOOD.
Assuming **higher ROE always means better performance**. ROE can rise due to increased leverage even when operations deteriorate – analyze DuPont components.
Using **Sales** instead of **COGS** as the numerator for Inventory Turnover (COGS is correct because inventory is valued at cost).
Confusing **Diluted EPS** with Basic EPS. Diluted EPS is always ≤ Basic EPS – dilution reduces EPS.
Thinking **earnings quality** is only about fraud. It also includes aggressive-but-legal accounting choices (capitalizing expenses, extending useful lives).
Ignoring **one-time items** when analyzing profitability trends. Always exclude non-recurring gains/losses to assess sustainable earnings.
Forgetting that **inventory growing faster than sales** is a red flag (potential obsolescence or demand slowdown).
Assuming **all leverage is bad**. Moderate leverage can enhance ROE if ROA > cost of debt.
Misclassifying **monetary vs non-monetary assets** under Temporal method – monetary = current rate, non-monetary = historical rate.
Not checking the **relationship between revenue and receivables** – AR growing faster than revenue indicates collection problems.
Using **total liabilities** in Debt-to-Equity when some analysts use only interest-bearing debt. Exam usually uses total liabilities unless specified.
summary: Financial Statement Analysis requires mastery of ratios across five categories (Liquidity, Leverage, Activity, Profitability, Market) and the ability to interpret them in context. Always use AVERAGES for balance sheet items when paired with income statement data. DuPont analysis (3-factor) decomposes ROE into Margin, Turnover, and Leverage – essential for diagnosing performance drivers. For foreign currency, distinguish Current Rate (OCI) from Temporal (Net Income) based on subsidiary independence. Earnings quality assessment involves comparing NI to CFO, identifying one-time items, and watching for aggressive accounting. Key red flags: inventory/AR growing faster than sales, DSO increasing, NI >> CFO, frequent accounting changes. Remember that ROE can be misleading without understanding its components.

quiz.question: Which ratio measures the ability of a firm to meet its short-term obligations with its most liquid assets?
quiz.explanation: The Quick Ratio excludes inventory and prepaids, using only Cash, Marketable Securities, and AR — the most liquid assets.

quiz.question: If a company's Asset Turnover increases while Profit Margin and Financial Leverage remain constant, ROE will:
quiz.explanation: DuPont: ROE = Margin × Turnover × Leverage. An increase in any component increases ROE.

quiz.question: Under the Current Rate Method of foreign currency translation, translation gains/losses are reported in:
quiz.explanation: Current Rate Method (independent subsidiary) → translation adjustment goes to OCI (equity).

quiz.question: The Cash Conversion Cycle equals:
quiz.explanation: CCC = Days Inventory Held + Days Sales Outstanding – Days Payables Outstanding.

quiz.question: In vertical analysis of an income statement, each item is expressed as a percentage of:
quiz.explanation: In vertical analysis of the income statement, Net Sales is the base (100%) and all items are expressed as a % of it.

essay.question: Analyst A claims that increasing financial leverage is always beneficial because it boosts ROE. 1) Explain how leverage impacts ROE using the DuPont framework. 2) Discuss the risks associated with this strategy. 3) Describe two red flags that would indicate low earnings quality.
essay.modelAnswer:
1. Leverage and ROE (DuPont):
ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier. Increasing debt raises the Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity). If ROA > after-tax cost of debt, leverage magnifies returns to shareholders.

2. Associated Risk:
Interest payments are fixed obligations. In a downturn, if ROA falls below the cost of debt, leverage works in reverse — drastically reducing ROE and potentially leading to insolvency. Higher leverage also increases the TIE risk (EBIT may not cover interest).

3. Earnings Quality Red Flags:
(a) Net Income significantly exceeds CFO — earnings are not converting to cash, suggesting aggressive accruals.
(b) Frequent changes in accounting estimates or policies — may indicate management is manipulating reported results.

summary: Financial Statement Analysis (20%) requires mastery of comparative techniques (horizontal, vertical, trend), all five ratio categories, the DuPont framework, profitability decomposition, and special issues (FX translation, inflation, earnings quality). Success means interpreting what ratios reveal about business health — not just calculating them.

test.question: Horizontal analysis compares financial data:
options: Across companies of the same size
As a percentage of total assets
As a percentage of net sales
test.explanation: Horizontal analysis tracks changes in financial data over multiple periods to identify trends.

test.question: In horizontal analysis, the base year figure is used as the:
test.explanation: % Change = (Current – Base) / Base. The base year is always the denominator.

test.question: Vertical analysis of the income statement expresses each item as a % of:
test.explanation: In income statement vertical analysis, Net Sales = 100% base.

test.question: Vertical analysis of the balance sheet expresses each item as a % of:
test.explanation: In balance sheet vertical analysis, Total Assets = 100% base.

test.question: Common-size financial statements are most useful for:
test.explanation: Common-size statements remove size differences, enabling meaningful cross-company comparison.

test.question: If revenue was $400K in Year 1 and $500K in Year 2, the horizontal analysis % change is:
Trend analysis uses a base year index of:
test.explanation: In trend analysis, the base year = 100. Subsequent years are expressed as an index relative to 100.

test.question: The Current Ratio formula is:
test.explanation: Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities.

test.question: The Quick Ratio excludes which current asset?
test.explanation: The Quick Ratio excludes inventory and prepaid expenses — the least liquid current assets.

test.question: The most conservative liquidity ratio is:
test.explanation: Cash Ratio = (Cash + Mkt Securities) / CL. Uses only the most liquid assets.

test.question: Net Working Capital equals:
test.explanation: NWC = Current Assets – Current Liabilities. A positive NWC indicates liquidity buffer.

test.question: A Current Ratio of 0.8 indicates:
test.explanation: CR < 1 means CL > CA — the company may struggle to meet short-term obligations.

test.question: A high Current Ratio may indicate:
options: Possible excess inventory or slow collections
test.explanation: High CR could mean obsolete inventory or uncollected AR — not necessarily good liquidity.

test.question: Times Interest Earned (TIE) is calculated as:
test.explanation: TIE = EBIT / Interest Expense. Measures how many times operating income covers interest.

test.question: A TIE ratio below 1.0 indicates:
options: The company cannot cover interest from operations
test.explanation: TIE < 1 means EBIT < Interest Expense — the company is burning cash to pay lenders.

test.question: Debt-to-Equity ratio equals:
test.explanation: D/E = Total Liabilities / Total Equity. Measures financial leverage.

test.question: The Equity Multiplier equals:
test.explanation: Equity Multiplier = Total Assets / Total Equity. Used in DuPont analysis.

test.question: Inventory Turnover is calculated using:
test.explanation: Inventory Turnover = COGS / Average Inventory. COGS (not Sales) is the correct numerator.

test.question: Days Inventory Outstanding (DIO) equals:
test.explanation: DIO = 365 / Inventory Turnover. Measures average days to sell inventory.

test.question: AR Turnover is calculated as:
test.explanation: AR Turnover = Net Credit Sales / Average AR. Measures collection efficiency.

test.question: Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) measures:
test.explanation: DSO = 365 / AR Turnover. Lower DSO = faster collection = better.

test.question: Days Payables Outstanding (DPO) measures:
test.explanation: DPO = 365 / AP Turnover. Higher DPO = company takes longer to pay suppliers (favorable for cash flow).

test.question: The Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC) equals:
test.explanation: CCC = Days Inventory + Days Sales Outstanding – Days Payables Outstanding.

test.question: A negative Cash Conversion Cycle means:
test.explanation: Negative CCC (e.g., Amazon) means the company collects cash before paying suppliers — suppliers finance operations.

test.question: Asset Turnover measures:
options: Revenue generated per dollar of assets
test.explanation: Asset Turnover = Net Sales / Average Total Assets. Measures asset productivity.

test.question: Gross Profit Margin equals:
test.explanation: Gross Profit Margin = Gross Profit / Net Sales. Measures pricing power and production efficiency.

test.question: Operating Profit Margin uses which income figure?
test.explanation: Operating Profit Margin = EBIT / Net Sales. Excludes interest and taxes.

test.question: EBITDA Margin is useful because it:
options: Approximates cash-generating ability before financing and taxes
test.explanation: EBITDA adds back D&A to operating income, approximating operating cash flow before financing/taxes.

test.question: ROA equals:
test.explanation: ROA = Net Income / Average Total Assets. Measures return on all assets regardless of financing.

test.question: ROE equals:
test.explanation: ROE = Net Income / Average Shareholders' Equity. The primary return metric for common shareholders.

test.question: The 3-factor DuPont formula for ROE is:
test.explanation: ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity).

test.question: In DuPont analysis, if ROE rises only because the Equity Multiplier increased, this indicates:
test.explanation: A rising Equity Multiplier means more debt relative to equity — higher financial risk, not better operations.

test.question: The 5-factor DuPont model adds which two components?
options: Asset turnover and fixed asset turnover
test.explanation: The 5-factor model splits the net profit margin into: Tax Burden (NI/EBT) × Interest Burden (EBT/EBIT) × EBIT Margin.

test.question: Basic EPS equals:
options: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Avg Common Shares
test.explanation: Basic EPS = (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares Outstanding.

test.question: Diluted EPS is always:
options: Equal to or less than Basic EPS
test.explanation: Diluted EPS includes the effect of convertible securities and options, which increase shares — reducing EPS.

test.question: The P/E ratio equals:
test.explanation: P/E = Market Price per Share / EPS. Shows how much investors pay per $1 of earnings.

test.question: A high P/E ratio typically indicates:
test.explanation: High P/E = investors expect high future growth OR the stock may be overvalued.

test.question: Dividend Yield equals:
test.explanation: Dividend Yield = Dividends per Share / Market Price. Measures income return on investment.

test.question: Dividend Payout Ratio equals:
test.explanation: Payout Ratio = Dividends per Share / EPS. Shows what % of earnings is paid as dividends.

test.question: Market-to-Book ratio greater than 1 indicates:
options: Market values the firm below accounting value
Market values the firm above accounting value
test.explanation: M/B > 1 means investors believe the firm is worth more than its accounting (book) value.

test.question: Book Value per Share equals:
test.explanation: Book Value per Share = (Total Equity – Preferred Equity) / Common Shares Outstanding.

test.question: The Operating Cycle equals:
test.explanation: Operating Cycle = Days Inventory + DSO. It excludes payables (unlike CCC).

test.question: Which activity ratio uses COGS in the numerator?
test.explanation: Inventory Turnover = COGS / Average Inventory. COGS is correct (not Sales).

test.question: If Inventory Turnover increases, Days Inventory Outstanding will:
test.explanation: DIO = 365 / Inventory Turnover. Higher turnover → fewer days to sell inventory.

test.question: A company with DSO of 45 days and DPO of 60 days has a favorable position because:
options: It collects faster than it pays
It pays faster than it collects
test.explanation: Collecting in 45 days but paying in 60 days means suppliers are financing operations — favorable cash position.

test.question: Under the Temporal Method, non-monetary assets are translated at:
test.explanation: Temporal Method: Non-monetary assets (inventory, PPE) use historical exchange rates.

test.question: Under the Current Rate Method, all assets and liabilities are translated at:
test.explanation: Current Rate Method translates all assets and liabilities at the current (closing) spot rate.

test.question: Remeasurement gains/losses under the Temporal Method are reported in:
test.explanation: Temporal Method (integrated subsidiary) → remeasurement gains/losses go directly to Net Income.

test.question: Translation adjustments under the Current Rate Method are reported in:
test.explanation: Current Rate Method → translation adjustment accumulates in OCI as Cumulative Translation Adjustment (CTA).

test.question: Which assets are classified as 'monetary' for Temporal Method purposes?
test.explanation: Monetary assets/liabilities have fixed dollar amounts: Cash, AR, AP, Notes Payable.

test.question: Revenue and expenses under the Current Rate Method are translated at:
test.explanation: Under the Current Rate Method, income statement items are translated at the average rate for the period.

test.question: High earnings quality is characterized by:
options: Net income much higher than CFO
test.explanation: High quality earnings are recurring, supported by operating cash flow, and based on conservative accounting.

test.question: A red flag for low earnings quality is:
test.explanation: When NI >> CFO, earnings are not converting to cash — suggesting aggressive accruals or manipulation.

test.question: Channel stuffing is an example of:
test.explanation: Channel stuffing involves pushing excess inventory to distributors to inflate reported revenue — low quality.

test.question: Capitalizing expenses that should be expensed results in:
test.explanation: Capitalizing costs defers expense recognition, inflating current period income — aggressive accounting.

test.question: Inflation distorts historical cost financial statements by:
options: Understating depreciation and inventory costs in real terms
test.explanation: Inflation means old assets and FIFO inventory are understated in real (current) dollar terms.

test.question: When comparing two companies, a lower net profit margin may still be acceptable if:
options: The company has much higher asset turnover (e.g., retail)
test.explanation: High-volume, low-margin businesses (retail) compensate with high asset turnover — DuPont shows this.

test.question: Which ratio best measures a company's ability to generate cash to service debt?
test.explanation: Cash Flow Ratio = CFO / Current Liabilities. Uses actual cash generated, not accrual-based figures.

test.question: If AR grows faster than revenue, this may indicate:
options: Collection problems or aggressive revenue recognition
test.explanation: AR growing faster than revenue suggests customers are not paying promptly or revenue is being recognized too early.

test.question: If inventory grows faster than revenue, this may indicate:
test.explanation: Inventory growing faster than revenue suggests products are not selling — potential obsolescence risk.

test.question: The Debt-to-Assets ratio measures:
options: What % of assets are financed by creditors
test.explanation: Debt-to-Assets = Total Debt / Total Assets. Shows the proportion of assets financed by debt.

test.question: A company with high operating leverage has:
options: High fixed costs relative to total costs
test.explanation: High operating leverage = high fixed costs. Profits are more sensitive to revenue changes.

test.question: EBITDA stands for:
options: Earnings Before Taxes and Depreciation Adjustments
Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization
Estimated Basis of Total Debt Allocation
Earnings Before Income Tax and Dividends Accrued
test.explanation: EBITDA = Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization.

test.question: Which ratio is most useful for comparing companies with different capital structures?
test.explanation: EBITDA Margin excludes interest (financing) and D&A (accounting choices), enabling better cross-company comparison.

test.question: Fixed Asset Turnover measures:
options: Revenue generated per dollar of net fixed assets
Fixed assets as % of total assets
test.explanation: Fixed Asset Turnover = Net Sales / Average Net Fixed Assets. Measures efficiency of long-term asset use.

test.question: When calculating ROA, the denominator should be:
test.explanation: ROA uses Average Total Assets because net income is earned over the period, not at a point in time.

test.question: Earnings Yield equals:
test.explanation: Earnings Yield = EPS / Market Price. It is the inverse of the P/E ratio.

test.question: A company has Net Income = $200K, Preferred Dividends = $20K, Common Shares = 90K. Basic EPS is:
Which of the following would DECREASE the Current Ratio?
options: Paying a current liability with cash
test.explanation: Buying inventory on credit increases both CA (inventory) and CL (AP) equally — but if CR > 1, this decreases it.

test.question: Which of the following would INCREASE the Quick Ratio?
test.explanation: Collecting AR converts a quick asset (AR) to cash — no change in numerator, but if it reduces CL, QR rises. Actually collecting AR doesn't change the QR numerator total (AR → Cash, both are quick assets). Paying off current liabilities with quick assets increases QR.

test.question: A company's ROE is 15%, ROA is 10%. The Equity Multiplier is approximately:
test.explanation: ROE = ROA × Equity Multiplier → 15% = 10% × EM → EM = 1.5.

test.question: If a company's Net Profit Margin is 5%, Asset Turnover is 2.0, and Equity Multiplier is 3.0, ROE is:
Declining gross margin over time most likely indicates:
options: Rising input costs or pricing pressure
test.explanation: Declining gross margin = COGS rising faster than revenue → input cost increases or competitive pricing pressure.

test.question: SG&A as a % of sales increasing over time suggests:
test.explanation: Rising SG&A % means overhead is growing faster than revenue — potential inefficiency.

test.question: The functional currency of a foreign subsidiary is determined by:
options: The currency of the primary economic environment where the subsidiary operates
The currency of the country where the parent is headquartered
The currency used for tax reporting
test.explanation: The functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment where the subsidiary operates.

test.question: Under the Temporal Method, COGS is translated at:
options: Historical rate (rate when inventory was purchased)
test.explanation: Temporal Method: COGS is translated at the historical rate (when the inventory was acquired).

test.question: A company's Inventory Turnover is 6. Its Days Inventory Outstanding is:
A company's DSO is 30 days and DPO is 45 days. Its operating cycle (DIO = 40 days) CCC is:
test.explanation: CCC = DIO + DSO – DPO = 40 + 30 – 45 = 25 days.

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of high earnings quality?
test.explanation: Large non-recurring gains are a sign of LOW earnings quality — they are not sustainable.

test.question: Book value per share would DECREASE if:
options: The company issues new shares at a premium
The company repurchases shares above book value
test.explanation: Repurchasing shares above book value reduces total equity more than it reduces share count, lowering BVPS.

test.question: Which ratio is most relevant for a creditor evaluating long-term solvency?
test.explanation: TIE measures how well EBIT covers interest — directly relevant to long-term debt service ability.

test.question: A company with a high dividend payout ratio is likely:
options: A mature company returning cash to shareholders
test.explanation: Mature companies with stable earnings tend to pay high dividends; growth companies retain earnings.

test.question: Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) uses which income figure?
test.explanation: ROCE = EBIT / Capital Employed. Uses EBIT to measure return before financing costs.

test.question: Capital Employed in ROCE equals:
test.explanation: Capital Employed = Total Assets – Current Liabilities (= Long-term Debt + Equity).

test.question: Frequent changes in accounting estimates are a sign of:
test.explanation: Frequent changes in estimates (useful life, bad debt %, warranty %) can be used to manage reported earnings.

test.question: Which method of foreign currency translation is used when the subsidiary's functional currency equals the parent's reporting currency?
test.explanation: Temporal Method (Remeasurement) is used when the subsidiary's functional currency = parent's reporting currency.

test.question: Under the Current Rate Method, equity accounts are translated at:
test.explanation: Equity accounts (common stock, APIC) are translated at historical rates under the Current Rate Method.

test.question: A company's P/E ratio is 20 and EPS is $3. The market price per share is:
test.explanation: Market Price = P/E × EPS = 20 × $3 = $60.

test.question: Which of the following would improve a company's Asset Turnover?
options: Increasing assets while holding sales constant
Increasing sales while holding assets constant
test.explanation: Asset Turnover = Sales / Assets. Increasing sales with the same asset base improves turnover.

test.question: The relationship between revenue and receivables is important because:
options: It reveals collection efficiency and potential revenue quality issues
test.explanation: If AR grows faster than revenue, it may signal collection problems or premature revenue recognition.

test.question: Which of the following is a market (valuation) ratio?
test.explanation: P/E is a market ratio — it relates market price to earnings per share.

test.question: A company has Total Assets = $1M, Total Equity = $400K. The Equity Multiplier is:
test.explanation: Equity Multiplier = Total Assets / Total Equity = $1M / $400K = 2.5.

test.question: Which of the following best describes 'economic value' vs 'book value'?
options: Economic value reflects future cash flows; book value uses historical cost
Economic value is based on GAAP
test.explanation: Economic value = PV of future cash flows. Book value = historical cost accounting. They differ significantly.

test.question: A company's gross margin declined from 40% to 35%. This most likely indicates:
test.explanation: Declining gross margin = COGS growing faster than revenue (input costs up or selling prices down).

test.question: Which of the following is the BEST indicator of a company's ability to pay dividends?
test.explanation: Dividends are paid in cash. CFO best indicates whether the company generates enough cash to sustain dividends.

test.question: Trend analysis with a base year index of 100 shows Year 3 revenue index of 140. This means:
options: Revenue grew 40% from the base year
test.explanation: Index 140 means revenue is 140% of base year — a 40% increase from the base year.

test.question: Which of the following would NOT be eliminated when computing the Quick Ratio?
test.explanation: AR is included in the Quick Ratio numerator. Inventory, prepaids, and supplies are excluded.

test.question: A company's Net Profit Margin is 8%, Asset Turnover is 1.5. Its ROA is:
test.explanation: ROA = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover = 8% × 1.5 = 12%.

test.question: Which of the following best describes 'financial leverage' in the DuPont framework?
test.explanation: The Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity) represents financial leverage in the 3-factor DuPont model.

test.question: A company reports Net Income of $500K and CFO of $150K. This pattern most likely indicates:
test.explanation: NI >> CFO suggests earnings are not converting to cash — a red flag for earnings quality.
